talks.title: Machine Learning Supercharged with Elixir
talks.summary: Machine learning is traditionally done on Python and Jupyter Notebooks, but a small team looked at the issues of the traditional way of doing things and the strengths of Elixir and made an amazing workflow. Ideally, the goal is to introduce people to the strengths of Elixir.
talks.speaker: Tan Jian Zhen

talks.title: Passwords are old, use WebAuthn
talks.summary: What if we could build our authentication processes in a way the user doesn’t need a password? I will give a quick overview of the past, present, and future of authentication. From basic authentication to passwordless biometric authentication using web authentication API, and everything in between.
talks.speaker: Mohammad Shahbaz Alam

talks.title: How to Create Pure CSS Games
talks.summary: Elad Shechter took his free time at home to create a pure CSS game. He will explain to you lots of tips and tricks on how to create pure CSS games, based on the Coronavirus game he made: https://codepen.io/elad2412/pen/wvabjXy.
talks.speaker: Elad Shechter

talks.title: (An introduction to) Domain Storytelling
talks.summary: Domain Storytelling is a collaborative modeling method. It brings together domain experts and development teams. It means that we let our users tell us stories about their work. While listening, we record the stories using a pictographic language.
talks.speaker: Henning Schwentner

talks.title: Choreography vs Orchestration in serverless microservices
talks.summary: Should there be a central orchestrator controlling all interactions between services or should each service work independently and only interact through shared events? In this talk, we’ll explore the Choreography vs Orchestration question and see demos of some of the tools that can help.
talks.speaker: Mete Atamel

talks.title: Social
talks.summary: Meet other people in our virtual space

talks.title: The 10,000 Steps of Open Source Project Health
talks.summary: In this talk, we will look at the approach that Facebook Open Source team takes to measure the current state of Facebook open source projects, and how we use these metrics to prioritize and to direct our DevRel focus. We aim to show how by looking at information about your open source communities.
talks.speaker: Dmitry Vinnik

talks.title: Everyone's a player (in a mid-90s MUD)
talks.summary: This talk takes the approach of applying Player Type Theory (from game design) to getting people involved and engaged in technical and documentation projects in a technical environment. Practical tips are offered for dealing with lack of engagement, human-caused delays, and even workplace bullying.
talks.speaker: Kenzie Woodbridge

talks.title: The Definitive Deep Dive into the .git Folder
talks.summary: What’s in the .git folder? We’ll dive deep into the objects folder, unpack commits, look at the types of DAG nodes, examine object content, and build a complete visualization of the stored content. We’ll also quickly look through Git hooks, Git config, and ref logs. Come experience the zen of git.
talks.speaker: Rob Richardson

talks.title: Demystifying the Java Flight Recorder API
talks.summary: This talk will be useful for developers who wish to monitor the performance of the applications especially in case of heavy data loads. It will help developers to understand how to use and integrate the JFR APIs in their existing Java based projects seamlessly along with the best practices.
talks.speaker: Karan Balkar

talks.title: Social
talks.summary: Meet other people in our virtual space
